newsitem.title: USA: US Sen D'Amato queries regulators on year 2000 bug.
newsitem.headline: US Sen D'Amato queries regulators on year 2000 bug.

text.p: Senate Banking Committee chairman Alfonse D'Amato said he asked top U.S. financial regulators for a status report on their oversight of institutions that could suffer from computer errors in the year 2000.

Many computers recognize only the last two digits of the year and could produce errors or cease to function when the date shifts from 1999 to 2000. Analysts have estimated it will cost companies and governments billions of dollars to correct the so-called millennium bug.
D'Amato said he sent letters last week to six regulators.

"The 'Year 2000' computer crisis will cause massive financial disruptions and jeopardize people's money," the New York Republican said. "Computers which don't know what year it is should be fixed so they can't wreak havoc on consumers and the American financial system."
D'Amato said he asked the regulators to monitor the situation closely and report to the Banking Committee by March 21.
